\u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>table&#xa0;3c\u003c/b>. summary of findings for cognitive outcomes.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003ch4>3.1.2 the impact of dhea, dheas and premature adrenarche on internalizing and externalizing traits\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">elevated dhea levels were generally associated with increased internalizing and externalizing symptoms compared to td peers, though effects varied by age and gender. barendse et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b51\">51\u003c/a>) found no direct association between levels of dhea and internalizing symptoms in girls aged 10-13; however, internalizing was associated with earlier pubertal maturation. mulligan et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b54\">54\u003c/a>) observed that heightened dhea levels in girls aged 8&#x2013;14 were associated with higher levels of anxiety, particularly increased panic/agoraphobia, generalized anxiety, and social anxiety. in girls and boys aged 8-12, average cortisol and high dhea levels were related to increased internalizing (\u003ca href=\"#b63\">63\u003c/a>). dhea was not related to internalizing or externalizing in girls or boys aged 11-13, however, low dhea levels were linked to increased internalizing symptoms in girls aged 14-16 (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>). goodyer et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b62\">62\u003c/a>) found that elevated evening cortisol and decreased morning dhea levels and high cortisol/dhea (c/d) ratios predicted the persistence of major depression in adolescents. additionally, in boys aged 9-14, higher dhea levels were linked to increased sad affect and emotional difficulties (\u003ca href=\"#b50\">50\u003c/a>). pajer et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b55\">55\u003c/a>) found no differences in dhea in girls aged 15&#x2013;17 with conduct disorder compared to controls, though they had lower c/d ratios, and girls with aggressive conduct disorder exhibited even lower ratios compared to those with non-aggressive conduct disorder.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">levels of dheas showed variable associations with internalizing and externalizing traits, as well as with cognitive outcomes. in comparison to girls with on-time adrenarche, girls aged 6&#x2013;8 with premature adrenarche (as inferred by high age-specific dheas levels) displayed increased internalizing and externalizing, with higher symptom scores for separation anxiety, specific phobia, panic/agoraphobia, depression, attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd), aggression, oppositional defiant disorder (odd), obsessive-compulsive disorder (ocd) and social problems (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">41\u003c/a>). sontag-padilla et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b49\">49\u003c/a>) found that girls with pa aged 6&#x2013;8 with low executive functioning exhibited higher internalizing and externalizing; however, these traits were not significant in girls with high executive functioning. dorn et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b44\">44\u003c/a>) also found increased internalizing and externalizing in girls and boys aged 6&#x2013;9 with pa (confirmed by increased dhea and dheas), with higher scores on withdrawal, somatic complaints, aggression, and social problems; they further reported lower scores for cognitive skills, encompassing verbal comprehension, perceptual organization, freedom from distractibility, and processing speed. in contrast, m&#xe4;ntyselk&#xe4; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b53\">53\u003c/a>) found no relationship between dheas and cognitive measures (abstract reasoning, pattern recognition, problem-solving skills) in boys and girls aged 6-8.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">neuroimaging studies have also reported evidence salient to relationships of dhea and dheas with internalizing and externalizing traits. thus, in nine-year-old girls and boys, high dhea levels were indirectly related to increased social anxiety and obsessive-compulsive symptoms through increased pituitary gland volume (\u003ca href=\"#b48\">48\u003c/a>). barendse et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b43\">43\u003c/a>) reported indirect, gender-specific effects of elevated dhea and dheas in nine-year-old children, with both boys and girls exhibiting reduced connectivity between the right amygdala and bilateral cerebellum; boys showed heightened social anxiety and obsessive-compulsive symptoms associated with increased left amygdala connectivity to the visual cortex, while girls with elevated dheas displayed reduced connectivity between the right amygdala and the right fusiform gyrus (ffa) and left insula, which was linked to decreases in social anxiety, specific phobia, and generalized anxiety. whittle et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b42\">42\u003c/a>) observed reduced activation in the mid-cingulate cortex in response to emotional faces in nine-year-old girls and boys; however, externalizing symptoms were found only in girls (internalizing was not assessed) and were linked to decreased posterior insula but increased ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmpfc) activation when viewing happy faces; girls also exhibited reduced activation in the subgenual cingulate cortex to happy faces and reduced activation in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlpfc) and striatum in response to negative emotional faces. in boys, elevated dhea levels at age nine were associated with increased amygdala connectivity with lateral prefrontal areas and the anterior cingulate cortex (acc) by age twelve, while elevated dheas levels were linked to increased amygdala-inferior frontal gyrus (ifg) connectivity over time, both of which were associated with increased anxiety symptoms; in contrast, girls with elevated dheas levels exhibited decreased amygdala-ifg connectivity over time, which was associated with reduced anxiety symptoms, and no significant differences in amygdala connectivity were observed in relation to changes in hormone levels (adrenarchal tempo) (\u003ca href=\"#b52\">52\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">in summary, of twelve studies that examined internalizing, seven found associations between elevated dhea or dheas levels and increased internalizing symptoms (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">41\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b43\">43\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b44\">44\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b49\">49\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b52\">52\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b54\">54\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b63\">63\u003c/a>), barendse et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b51\">51\u003c/a>) reported no association, shirtcliff et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>) found an inverse relationship in older adolescents, and three studies found increased c/d ratios (\u003ca href=\"#b62\">62\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b64\">64\u003c/a>). out of nine studies that examined externalizing, six reported increased externalizing traits associated with elevated dhea or dheas (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">41\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b42\">42\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b44\">44\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b47\">47\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b49\">49\u003c/a>), shirtcliff et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>) found no association, and pajer et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b55\">55\u003c/a>) noted no differences in dheas levels between conduct disorder cases and controls but an increased c/d ratio.\u003c/p>\u003ch4>3.1.3 the impact of dhea, dheas and premature adrenarche on social outcomes\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">studies that assessed social outcomes in relation to dhea reported varied outcomes. girls exhibited higher dhea levels and engaged more frequently in prosocial behaviors in comparison to boys; however, no significant relationship was found between dhea and prosocial behavior in five-year old girls or boys (\u003ca href=\"#b56\">56\u003c/a>), or for girls or boys aged 8-9 (\u003ca href=\"#b47\">47\u003c/a>). similarly, assessments of social dominance behaviors showed no associations with dhea levels in five-year-old girls or boys (\u003ca href=\"#b56\">56\u003c/a>) or in girls aged 10-14 (\u003ca href=\"#b57\">57\u003c/a>). girls aged 11&#x2013;13 with high c/d ratios reported more negative life events (\u003ca href=\"#b62\">62\u003c/a>), and shirtcliff et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>) found that 11-16-year-old girls and boys, particularly girls with internalizing problems, exhibited a heightened dhea response to a peer evaluation task, both in a laboratory and naturalistic setting (diurnal rhythm), with internalizing associated with more negative life events, rumination, and emotion-focused coping. howland et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b46\">46\u003c/a>) did not find any differences in dhea levels in previously institutionalized girls and boys aged 7&#x2013;15 compared to controls, though they found positive c/d coupling, where high cortisol levels coincide with high dhea levels, in both groups. however, in contrast to non-adopted children, there was no c/d coupling in early adrenarchal stages, but cortisol and dhea became coupled in later pubertal stages. in girls and boys aged 9-16, a positive c/d coupling was observed in response to a social performance task, with older adolescents exhibiting stronger coupling (\u003ca href=\"#b58\">58\u003c/a>). while elevated dhea levels alone were linked to a more typical cortisol response to trauma-induced stress, higher dhea/cortisol ratios were associated with a stronger link between childhood maltreatment and reduced cortisol responses, suggesting an adrenal-specific adaptation (\u003ca href=\"#b65\">65\u003c/a>). lastly, pantell et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b60\">60\u003c/a>) found no relationship between dhea and cumulative social adversity in boys aged 0-17.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">social-emotional challenges related to dhea may also extend to early adversity. high dhea levels were associated with socioeconomic disadvantage, indicating early adversity; however, no relationship was found with family dysfunction, in girls and boys aged 0-5 (\u003ca href=\"#b59\">59\u003c/a>). lower levels of parental supportiveness and higher levels of father-reported marital conflict and depression during the preschool years predicted pa in both boys and girls aged 6-7, and mother&#x2019;s age at menarche and socioeconomic status (ses) predicted the timing of sexual development in daughters at age eleven (\u003ca href=\"#b45\">45\u003c/a>). high cortisol and low dhea levels were linked to increased emotional regulation and likability among peers and adults in both sexes aged 8-12, despite higher maltreatment in girls, with girls having higher dhea levels compared to boys (\u003ca href=\"#b63\">63\u003c/a>). in addition, blunted (decreased) hpa-axis reactivity, reflected in lower cortisol/dheas ratios, was observed in girls and boys aged 13&#x2013;16 exposed to greater interpersonal violence, and was found to mediate the positive association between such exposure and increased externalizing psychopathology (\u003ca href=\"#b61\">61\u003c/a>). cardoos et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b57\">57\u003c/a>) found no relationship between dhea and ses in girls aged 10-14; however, ses positively predicted risk-taking behavior. in girls and boys aged 9-16, marceau et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b58\">58\u003c/a>) observed increased c/d coupling in response to a parent-child conflict task, however shirtcliff et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>) reported reduced dhea levels in girls and boys aged 11-16. high dhea levels were associated with less confiding in one&#x2019;s mother and less maternal support in girls aged 12-16, and lower dhea levels were initially linked to higher attachment anxiety, though this relationship lost significance after controlling for cortisol (\u003ca href=\"#b66\">66\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">of thirteen studies that examined social outcomes in relation to dhea, dheas, or c/d ratios, five found elevated levels in relation to negative social outcomes, including negative life events, maltreatment, or family conflict (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b45\">45\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b58\">58\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b62\">62\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b65\">65\u003c/a>). five studies found no association between dhea levels and prosocial or dominance behaviors (\u003ca href=\"#b46\">46\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b47\">47\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b56\">56\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b57\">57\u003c/a>) or with cumulative social adversity (\u003ca href=\"#b60\">60\u003c/a>). two studies linked high dhea levels to socioeconomic disadvantage (\u003ca href=\"#b45\">45\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b59\">59\u003c/a>), whereas cardoos et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b57\">57\u003c/a>) observed no relationship between dhea and ses.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">overall, elevated dhea and dheas levels were associated with increased internalizing and externalizing symptoms, although these effects varied by age, gender, and context. neuroimaging studies also showed that heightened dhea and dheas levels were related to changes in brain connectivity, influencing emotional and behavioral traits like anxiety and externalizing behaviors. studies on dhea and dheas and social outcomes showed mixed results, with no relationship found between dhea or dheas and prosociality or social competence; however, increased responsivity was found in response to social stress tasks.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>3.2 results for systematic review 2: altered adrenarche timing and dhea(s) levels in relation to social cognition\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">this section investigates how alterations in adrenarche timing and dhea(s) levels may contribute to the manifestation of asd by examining whether dhea(s) levels differ in asd children compared to neurotypical children, as well as the relationships with dhea(s) and social impairments in asd, specifically focusing on androgenic enzyme activity and sex-based differences.\u003c/p>\u003ch4>3.2.1 different sampling methods\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">a summary of each study reviewed for systematic review 2 can be found in \u003ca href=\"#t6\">table&#xa0;4\u003c/a>. different methods were utilized between studies in measuring dhea(s) and in assessing asd. six studies measured only dhea or dheas (\u003ca href=\"#b67\">67\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>) and five measured both (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>). in eight studies, children were diagnosed or had a previous diagnosis based on dsm-iv criteria (\u003ca href=\"#b67\">67\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b76\">76\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b79\">79\u003c/a>), based on dsm-5 criteria in three studies (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>), based on icd-10 or dsm-iii-r criteria by lakato&#x161;ov&#xe1; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>), and tordjman et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>),, respectively, and geier &amp; geier (\u003ca href=\"#b80\">80\u003c/a>) did not specify. nine studies evaluated only boys with asd (\u003ca href=\"#b67\">67\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b76\">76\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>), with five evaluating both girls and boys (\u003ca href=\"#b70\">70\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b79\">79\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b80\">80\u003c/a>). six studies provided measures of asd social impairments (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>), and three examined the association between dhea(s) levels and autism severity as measured by the childhood autism rating scale (cars) (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table&#xa0;4\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t006.jpg\" name=\"table&#xa0;4\" target=\"_blank\">\n \u003cpicture>\n \u003csource type=\"image/webp\" \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>table&#xa0;4\u003c/b>. articles selected for review for systematic review 2 (q2a-b; \u003ci>altered adrenarchal timing and dhea(s) levels leading to maladaptation in social cognition\u003c/i>), alongside extracted information on participant sex and age, which measurements were used to assess adrenarche and diagnose asd and/or related traits, and key findings in terms of dhea and dheas.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003ch4>3.2.2 altered dhea and dheas levels in children with asd\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">findings of dhea levels in children with asd varied by sex and age; whether dhea and dheas levels\r\nin autistic boys and girls are elevated compared to controls or reference ranges is summarized in\r\n\u003ca href=\"#t7\">table&#xa0;5\u003c/a>. among studies examining only boys with asd, four reported elevated dhea levels in comparison to neurotypical controls in five-year-olds (\u003ca href=\"#b67\">67\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>), in boys aged 4-5 (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>) and in boys aged 3-10 (\u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>). in contrast, three found no differences in dhea levels in asd boys aged 3-5 (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>) or in boys aged 4&#x2013;8 (\u003ca href=\"#b76\">76\u003c/a>). el-baz et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>) found increased hyperandrogenemia, defined as androgen levels (including dhea) exceeding two standard deviations above age- and pubertal stage-matched reference ranges, and more advanced tanner stages in asd boys aged 6-15; however, dhea was not significantly associated with presence \u003ci>vs\u003c/i> absence of asd. of studies that examined both boys and girls, three found elevated dhea in girls and boys aged 4-8 (\u003ca href=\"#b80\">80\u003c/a>), 7-15 (\u003ca href=\"#b79\">79\u003c/a>), and 13-14 (\u003ca href=\"#b70\">70\u003c/a>). geier &amp; geier (2006) also found increased hyperandrogenicity in asd girls and boys, with 94% exhibiting one or more signs. majewska et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>) found that dhea levels increased significantly in asd between the ages 3&#x2013;4 and 7&#x2013;9 in girls and boys, whereas levels decreased in neurotypical controls.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table&#xa0;5\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t007.jpg\" name=\"table&#xa0;5\" target=\"_blank\">\n \u003cpicture>\n \u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=480&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t007.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 563px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=370&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t007.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 1024px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" 1441px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" media=\"\">\u003csource type=\"image/jpg\" srcset=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t007.jpg\" media=\"\"> \u003cimg \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>table&#xa0;5\u003c/b>. summary of dhea(s) findings in asd children from each study, organized in order of age range.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cp class=\"mb15 w100pc float_left mt15\">findings of dheas levels in children with asd also show notable variation among studies. of studies that only examined boys, five found no differences in dheas levels in 5-year-old boys with asd (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>) or in asd boys aged 3-5 (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>), 3-8 (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>), or 8&#x2013;9 (\u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>); mills et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b76\">76\u003c/a>) found no difference in mean dheas levels in asd boys aged 4&#x2013;8 compared to controls, however asd boys were more likely to have detectable levels of dheas, suggesting potential earlier adrenal activation. croonenberghs et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b68\">68\u003c/a>) reported higher 5-htp-induced dheas levels and greater cd ratios in asd boys aged 13-19. lastly, for studies that assessed both girls and boys, majewska et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>) found that in comparison to 3-4-year-old girls and boys with asd, boys aged 7-9 (but not girls) exhibited increased dheas compared to neurotypical controls, finding that dheas levels increased between the two age groups in both asd and neurotypical girls and boys. geier &amp; geier (\u003ca href=\"#b79\">79\u003c/a>) found lower dheas levels in asd boys aged 7&#x2013;15 compared to laboratory age- and sex-specific reference ranges.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">some studies yielded findings suggesting alterations in androgen-related pathways involving dhea(s) in boys with asd. in the &#x2018;frontdoor&#x2019; androgen pathway, pregnenolone is first converted to 17-oh pregnenolone by cyp17a1, and then to dhea by the same enzyme through its 17/20 lyase activity; jans&#xe1;kov&#xe1; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>) found increased dhea/pregnenolone and dheas/pregnenolone-sulfate ratios in autistic boys aged 4&#x2013;6 compared to neurotypical controls, suggesting heightened 17,20-lyase activity. in addition, they found increased sult2a1 activity, which sulfates dhea to dheas, which can then be converted back to dhea; increased activity could contribute to a higher availability of dhea as a substrate for cyp17a1. while gasser et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b70\">70\u003c/a>) found higher 17,20-lyase activity of cyp17a1 based on metabolite ratios, around 150% higher in boys with asd, as well as a higher dc ratio, suggesting a trend towards increased dhea production over cortisol. geier &amp; geier (\u003ca href=\"#b80\">80\u003c/a>) found that dhea levels were almost 200% higher in asd girls and boys compared to laboratory-specific age-matched reference ranges, and found reduced levels of glutathione, a peptide that hinders the conversion of dhea to&#xa0;dheas, potentially leading to the production of less dheas in comparison with dhea. this inference is supported by their later findings of lower dheas in boys and girls aged 7-15 (\u003ca href=\"#b79\">79\u003c/a>). four out of seven studies assessing dheas found no differences in levels compared to controls, and of these studies, six examined only boys.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">in sum, results indicate a pattern of elevated dhea levels in asd compared to neurotypical controls, with seven out of eleven studies finding statistically significant increases, and eight studies assessing dhea examined only boys. dheas levels are consistently not significant, with four out of seven studies that assessed dheas finding no differences compared to neurotypical controls, and six studies assessing dheas examined only boys.\u003c/p>\u003ch4>3.2.3 the impact of dhea and dheas on asd social interaction differences and trait severity\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">most studies found no relationship between dhea(s), social interaction differences, and asd trait\r\nseverity (see \u003ca href=\"#t8\">table&#xa0;6\u003c/a> for a summary). jan&#x161;&#xe1;kov&#xe1; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>) found a significant positive relationship of dhea and dheas with reciprocal social interaction (social affect) and communication (core domains assessed via the autism observation schedule) in asd boys aged 4-6. three studies found no relationship between dhea and social communication differences in five-year-old boys (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>), in boys aged 4-5 (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>), or in boys aged 6-15 (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>). additionally, neither hassan et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>) or tordjman et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>) found significant associations between dhea or dheas, respectively, and social communication impairments in boys aged 3-8. of studies that assessed asd severity using the cars, el-baz et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>) found a positive correlation with dhea in asd boys aged 7-16, and sririam et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>) found no relationship with dheas in boys aged 8-9. girls and boys aged 7&#x2013;9 with asd exhibited relationships with both dhea and dheas; significant moderate positive correlations were found for girls, whereas non-significant weak negative correlations were found for boys (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table&#xa0;6\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\u003ca \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>table&#xa0;6\u003c/b>. summary of dhea(s) impacts on asd traits from each study, organized in order of age range.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cp class=\"mb15 w100pc float_left mt15\">overall, out of seven studies that examined dhea in relation to social communication impairments or overall symptom severity, five found no relationship with dhea levels (\u003ca href=\"#b69\">69\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>), all examining only boys with asd compared to controls. out of four studies that examined dheas, three found no relationship between dheas and social communication (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b78\">78\u003c/a>), with only one of these studies including both girls and boys (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">considered together, these findings suggest increased levels of dhea in asd children and generally unaltered dheas levels, with differences in androgen-pathways in asd children. increased activity in androgenic enzymes like cyp17a1 and sult2a1 may drive higher dhea production. most studies did not find significant associations between dhea(s) levels and social or communication impairments in asd or with symptom severity. notably, the research predominantly focuses on boys, leaving a gap in understanding these patterns in girls with asd.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>3.3 results for systematic review 3: impact of dhea and dheas on repetitive behaviors and restricted interests\u003c/h3>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">this section examines the potential links between altered adrenarche timing, variation in dhea and dheas levels, and the presence of repetitive behaviors and restricted interests in asd. by analyzing the relationship between adrenal hormones and these asd traits across different ages, this section aims to clarify if hormonal variations during middle childhood contribute to shifts in these asd-related phenotypes.\u003c/p>\u003ch4>3.3.1 different sampling methods\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">a summary of each study reviewed for systematic review 3 can be found in \u003ca href=\"#t9\">table&#xa0;7\u003c/a>. studies differed in methods of assessing dhea(s) and asd traits. he et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>) measured only dhea, two studies measured only dheas (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b81\">81\u003c/a>), and three studies measured both (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>). three used the autism diagnostic observation schedule and the autism diagnostic interview to measure asd traits; tordjman et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>) utilized the first edition, and two used the second edition (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>). in addition, lakatosov&#xe1; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>) used the behavior problems inventory, he et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>) used the repetitive behavior scale, and erbay et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b81\">81\u003c/a>) studied children with chronic tic disorder or tourette&#x2019;s syndrome via the yale global tic severity scale. two studies utilized the childhood autism rating scale (cars), which includes measures related to repetitive behaviors and restricted interests, including object and body use and adaptation to change (\u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>), however majewska et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>) only focused on overall cars scores, not reporting any results for specific cars measurements. four studies assessed only boys (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>&#x2013;\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>), and two assessed both boys and girls (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b81\">81\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"imageheaders\">table&#xa0;7\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"figuredesc\">\u003ca href=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t009.jpg\" name=\"table&#xa0;7\" target=\"_blank\">\n \u003cpicture>\n \u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=480&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t009.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 563px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=370&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t009.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: 1024px)\">\u003csource type=\"image/webp\" srcset=\"https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=290&f=webp/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t009.jpg\" media=\"(max-width: media=\"\">\u003csource type=\"image/jpg\" srcset=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t009.jpg\" media=\"\"> \u003cimg src=\"https://www.frontiersin.org/files/articles/1576392/fpsyt-16-1576392-html/image_m/fpsyt-16-1576392-t009.jpg\" alt=\"www.frontiersin.org\" id=\"t9\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>table&#xa0;7\u003c/b>. articles selected for review for systematic review 3 (q3a-d; \u003ci>impact of dhea and dheas on repetitive behaviors and restricted interests\u003c/i>), alongside extracted information on participant sex and age, which measurements were used to assess adrenarche and asd traits, and key findings in terms of dhea and dheas.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003ch4>3.3.2 the impact of dhea and dheas on repetitive behaviors and restricted interests\u003c/h4>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">most studies did not find any relationship between dhea(s) and repetitive and restricted behaviors in children with asd. while lakatosov&#xe1; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b75\">75\u003c/a>) found a negative correlation between dheas and restricted and repetitive behaviors in boys aged 2-5, they did not find a significant relationship with dhea or dheas in boys aged 5&#x2013;6 or aged 7-9. similarly, tordjman et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b73\">73\u003c/a>) and he et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>) found no relationship between dheas or dhea, respectively, and repetitive behaviors in boys aged 3-8. erbay et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b81\">81\u003c/a>) found higher dheas levels in girls and boys aged 7&#x2013;12 with chronic tic disorder or tourette&#x2019;s syndrome; however, there was no correlation with tic severity. in contrast, jans&#xe1;kov&#xe1; et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>) found a significant relationship between both dhea and dheas and restricted and repetitive behaviors in boys with asd aged 4-6, and majewska et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>) found a positive correlation between dhea (but not dheas) and cars scores autistic girls aged 7-9, and a negative correlation in boys aged 7-9. hassan et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b71\">71\u003c/a>) found no significant relationship between dhea and cars items in boys 4-11.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">most studies found no consistent relationship between dhea or dheas levels and repetitive behaviors or restricted interests in asd, though a few studies noted correlations within specific age and gender subgroups. overall, the findings suggest limited and variable associations, highlighting a need for more research in this area.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h5\" name=\"h5\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>4 discussion\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">autism has many causes, but they all converge on the presence of maladaptation in central aspects of social development. given that middle childhood represents a key period during the development of social abilities in children, it should not be unexpected that alterations to this stage may modulate the onset, expression or symptoms of asd or autism spectrum traits that develop and become evident between the ages of about 7 and 11. this hypothesis was motivated by the discovery by zhang et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b20\">20\u003c/a>) of a genetically-based subtype of asd that is diagnosed mainly during middle childhood, and that involves the expression of a suite of psychological traits, such as increased internalizing, that are notably distinct from those in earlier-diagnosed forms.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">the main goal of this article has been to present and evaluate the hypothesis that the social adaptations initiated by adrenarche, mediated by increased expression of dhea and/or dheas, are selectively altered or underdeveloped in this later-developing subtype of autism. these social adaptations include, for example, the acquisition of sociocultural norms, local to global shifts in information processing, development of advanced theory of mind skills including recursion (&#x2018;he thinks that she thinks that&#x2026;&#x2019;), complex moral reasoning, enhanced social communication skills including prosody of speech, sarcasm, irony, verbal competition, and gossip, increasingly-complex social competition in play, and an increased sense of gender and sexual identity (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">15\u003c/a>). indeed, from an evolutionary perspective, humans exhibit an extraordinarily long pre-adult period, including a stage unique to humans and other great apes, middle childhood, when the brain is nearly fully developed in size while the body remains relatively small (\u003ca href=\"#b16\">16\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b17\">17\u003c/a>). diverse evidence indicates that the adaptive significance of middle childhood involves social learning, such that children in this stage have been selected to optimally (and in relatively safe contexts) acquire key social skills that will be beneficial in later life in the contexts of adult social and sexual competition and cooperation (\u003ca href=\"#b15\">15\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b29\">29\u003c/a>). as such, middle childhood is expected to represent an important critical period in social development, making it a potential point of vulnerability with regard to underdeveloped or dysregulated social maturation, and with regard to an increase in social challenges that may make pre-existing autism-related traits more evident and problematic.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">the primary goals of the systematic reviews conducted have been to evaluate the presence and strength of evidence relating adrenarche and dhea and/or dheas to asd and autism-related traits, in endocrinological, neurological, and psychological contexts. the main findings of the systematic reviews are two-fold. first, considerable evidence links both dhea and dheas with a set of psychological and psychiatric traits related to asd, especially in the context of internalizing and externalizing disorders. findings in this regard point toward increased social anxiety (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">41\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b43\">43\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b44\">44\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b48\">48\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b54\">54\u003c/a>), potentially mediated by the role of dhea and dheas in responses to social stress (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>). dhea and cortisol become increasingly coupled throughout puberty (\u003ca href=\"#b46\">46\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b58\">58\u003c/a>), potentially to facilitate adaptive stress responses in the context of increasing social and emotional demands (\u003ca href=\"#b64\">64\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b65\">65\u003c/a>). girls with internalizing symptoms and social anxiety display sharper increases in dhea during social challenges compared to boys and adolescents without internalizing symptoms, and elevated cortisol/dhea ratios were linked to more persistent depressive symptoms; increased negative life events and ruminative coping styles in these girls may result in a more chronic release of dhea that contributes to maladaptive stress responses (\u003ca href=\"#b40\">40\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b62\">62\u003c/a>). elevated dhea and dheas levels may also be related to higher levels of social anxiety through their associations with increased pituitary gland volume; larger pituitary gland volumes have been associated with hpa axis hyperactivity, potentiating heightened stress sensitivity that increases risk for psychopathology (\u003ca href=\"#b48\">48\u003c/a>). elevated dhea and dheas levels in girls have thus been associated with a higher probability and increased severity of anxiety, particularly social anxiety (\u003ca href=\"#b54\">54\u003c/a>), and higher symptom scores for aggression, adhd, odd, and ocd have been found in children with premature adrenarche (which is associated with higher dhea) (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">41\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b44\">44\u003c/a>). these findings are generally consilient with the middle childhood autism phenotype described by zhang et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b20\">20\u003c/a>), which is characterized by a trajectory of intensifying social-emotional difficulties during middle to late childhood; this later-developing asd subtype also exhibits moderate-to-high genetic correlations with internalizing disorders, adhd, and trauma-related factors (e.g. childhood maltreatment, adverse childhood experiences, and ptsd). taken together, the studies reviewed here thus support the idea that alterations to aspects of dhea and dheas metabolism in middle childhood may be involved in phenotypes associated with the later-diagnosed subtype of asd.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">the second line of evidence reviewed here implicates elevated dhea levels in children with asd, aligning with the results from a recent meta-analysis by wang et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b82\">82\u003c/a>) who found significantly higher levels of androgens, including dhea, androstendione, and testosterone, along with weak or negative associations with dheas, among individuals diagnosed with asd compared to controls. altered levels of dhea precursors and metabolites, as well as increased activity of enzymes responsible for dhea synthesis and metabolism, including increased cyp17 17,20-lyase activity, may increase dhea availability (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b79\">79\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b80\">80\u003c/a>). gasser et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b70\">70\u003c/a>) found a low ratio of glucocorticoids to androgens in children with asd, further supporting a role for increased cyp17a1 activity and a shift toward increased production of androgens. while the source of dhea could be of neural or gonadal origin, studies assessing prepubertal individuals were able to rule out gonadal sources (\u003ca href=\"#b74\">74\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b77\">77\u003c/a>), and dhea levels exhibit strong positive association with levels of total testosterone and free testosterone, suggesting a common adrenal source (\u003ca href=\"#b67\">67\u003c/a>). hormonal imbalances involving increased dhea and testosterone provide a potential biochemical framework that could underpin the neurobiological mechanisms linking dhea and dheas to the development of autism-related social-emotional traits, especially in girls (\u003ca href=\"#b41\">41\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b44\">44\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b49\">49\u003c/a>). such findings are consistent with hypotheses that posit roles for elevated androgen levels in the development of asd (\u003ca href=\"#b22\">22\u003c/a>), and with effects of prenatal dhea levels on aspects of infant emotional reactivity (\u003ca href=\"#b83\">83\u003c/a>). considered together, these primary findings support the hypothesis that alterations to dhea, adrenarche, and middle childhood social adaptations may mediate the expression of cases of asd with a middle to late childhood age of expression and diagnosis.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">although direct evidence linking dhea and dheas to social-emotional behavior is limited, neuroimaging findings from the reviewed articles provide further insights into how these hormones may influence psychological and cognitive traits. thus, for example, among boys and girls around 10 years in age, higher levels of dhea levels have been associated with reduced affect-related brain activity in the mid-cingulate cortex (for both sexes), and, among girls only, in various cortical and subcortical regions (\u003ca href=\"#b42\">42\u003c/a>). higher dhea levels have also been associated with increased externalizing symptoms in females, an association that was partly mediated by posterior insula activation to happy facial expressions. further implicating effects on emotionality, dhea has been found to influence amygdala-ifg connectivity, which is involved in downregulating amygdala responses to emotional stimuli, with elevated levels relating to increased connectivity and anxiety in boys but reduced connectivity and anxiety in girls (\u003ca href=\"#b52\">52\u003c/a>). sex differences in the effects of dhea and dheas on amygdala connectivity may stem from increased androgen receptor density in boys due to elevated prenatal testosterone exposure, where lower testosterone levels and fewer androgen receptors in girls could allow dhea and dheas greater binding opportunities (\u003ca href=\"#b52\">52\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">barendse et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b43\">43\u003c/a>) found that elevated dhea in boys increased amygdala-visual cortex connectivity, contributing to heightened social anxiety, while elevated dheas in girls decreased amygdala connectivity to the left insula and ffa, resulting in reduced social anxiety (\u003ca href=\"#b43\">43\u003c/a>). reduced amygdala-insula connectivity may diminish the intensity of emotional responses to negative stimuli, while reduced connectivity with the ffa may weaken the recognition and interpretation of emotional facial expressions, potentially reducing attention to socially threatening cues by dampening emotional reactivity but also limiting the ability to detect and appropriately respond to nuanced social and emotional signals (\u003ca href=\"#b84\">84\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b85\">85\u003c/a>). increased amygdala-visual cortex connectivity in boys may also heighten sensitivity to social cues by amplifying the amygdala&#x2019;s response to novel or ambiguous social stimuli, leading to an over-emphasis on these cues in social situations (\u003ca href=\"#b86\">86\u003c/a>). in this context, individuals with asd often exhibit impaired judgment of facial expressions, inaccurately labeling neutral faces as negatively valenced, with reduced eye contact correlating with increased amygdala reactivity and threat ratings (\u003ca href=\"#b87\">87\u003c/a>). amygdala dysfunction is also common in asd and has been associated with social anxiety, sensory over-responsivity, and social-communication impairments (\u003ca href=\"#b88\">88\u003c/a>). together, the evidence suggests that elevated dhea and dheas can influence cognitive and&#xa0;emotional behaviors by altering brain activation and functional connectivity in ways that can promote either adaptive or maladaptive development.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">further neuroimaging studies support the role of dhea and dheas in mediating middle childhood adaptations. heightened dhea levels have thus been associated with negative structural covariance between the amygdala and the occipital lobe, parietal lobe, and acc (cortical thickening in these regions decreased with increasing amygdala volume), resulting in improved visual awareness, visuo-motor dexterity, and reduced attention problems, respectively; dhea may thus promote a shift from a bottom-up, amygdala-driven attentional processing system, strongly influenced by emotional responses, to a top-down, more deliberate and goal-directed system (\u003ca href=\"#b89\">89\u003c/a>). attentional control develops significantly in middle childhood as children improve their ability to suppress distractions and shift attention, potentially to allow for better sustained attention; initially strong distractibility in children aged 6&#x2013;10 decreases over time, indicating rapid learning and adaptation during this period (\u003ca href=\"#b90\">90\u003c/a>). furthermore, a positive age-specific association between dhea and cortical thickening was found in the right temporoparietal junction (rtpj) between the ages 7-12 (\u003ca href=\"#b91\">91\u003c/a>). the rtpj is involved in directing attention towards relevant social stimuli, guided by the acc to potentially help prioritize and attend to relevant social cues (\u003ca href=\"#b92\">92\u003c/a>). more complex tom abilities arise starting around age seven, including understanding recursive mental states (understanding that someone can have a belief about another person&#x2019;s belief), nonliteral language (including irony and sarcasm), and recognizing faux pas, contributing to successful social integration (\u003ca href=\"#b18\">18\u003c/a>). the rtpj&#x2019;s role within the ventral attention and tom networks enables it to update one&#x2019;s understanding of another&#x2019;s mental state in response to new information, thus facilitating the development of cognitive empathy, which develops between the ages of around 10-12 (\u003ca href=\"#b93\">93\u003c/a>). overall, dhea and dheas may thus facilitate the acquisition of emotional processing and regulation abilities, attentional control, and enhanced tom development during middle childhood.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">taken together, these findings suggest that high levels of dhea and dheas, developing through early adrenarche timing and elevated social stress reactivity, may impact the acquisition of middle childhood adaptations, leading to maladaptation in the context of autism-related traits (\u003ca href=\"#f1\">figure&#xa0;1\u003c/a>). by this model, alterations to levels of dhea and dheas impact the adaptive function of these hormones with regard to social opportunities and threats. while moderate dhea levels can thus promote positive adaptations, including limiting emotional salience in stressful social contexts, potentially to support peer integration and bottom-up to top-down attentional processing (\u003ca href=\"#b89\">89\u003c/a>), exaggerated levels due to early adrenarche timing or other causes may lead to maladaptive outcomes, including an increased sensitivity to threatening and ambiguous social stimuli and reduced interoceptive processing (\u003ca href=\"#b42\">42\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"#b43\">43\u003c/a>). these results are consistent with the middle childhood autism trajectory described by zhang et&#xa0;al. (\u003ca href=\"#b20\">20\u003c/a>), which is characterized by positive genetic correlations with internalizing disorders and social-emotional difficulties that escalate during this developmental stage. by positioning adrenarche as a key biological substrate for these changes, this study underscores the potential for middle childhood to act as a critical period in shaping asd traits through the interplay of endocrine, environmental, and neurodevelopmental factors. such insights reinforce the need to further investigate the mechanisms through which altered adrenarche timing and dhea(s) levels contribute to the heterogeneity of asd, with a focus on middle childhood as a sensitive window for intervention and support. such investigations should include prospective longitudinal studies of both dhea(s) hormone levels and social behavior, in relation to the nature and intensity of social challenges, across the adrenarche transition.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv through altered brain maturation and middle childhood adaptations to various psychological issues. it highlights genetic factors and early stressors leading to increased stress responses and potential maladaptive outcomes, including cognitive and social difficulties, and psychological problems. these are linked to a middle childhood asd subtype.\" id=\"f1\" loading=\"lazy\">\n \u003c/picture>\n\u003c/a>\u003cp>\u003cb>figure&#xa0;1\u003c/b>. simplified theoretical model for role of dhea(s) in the development of middle childhood asd subtypes. see text for details.\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"dottedline\">\u003c/div>\u003cp class=\"mb15 w100pc float_left mt15\">one important limitation of this study is the variability in methodologies and sample characteristics across the reviewed articles, particularly the limited number of studies directly assessing how dhea and dheas impact traits associated with asd, especially repetitive behaviors and restricted interests (rrbs). results from the reviewed studies underscore this gap, as there were few studies of relationships between dhea and dheas levels and these traits. in contrast to these results, dhea, or dheas levels have been reported as higher among individuals with childhood obsessive compulsive disorder (ocd) (\u003ca href=\"#b94\">94\u003c/a>), and tic disorder (\u003ca href=\"#b95\">95\u003c/a>) compared to controls, and for both disorders the usual age of onset occurs around the age of adrenarche, for pediatric cases. given the comorbidities of asd with ocd and tic disorder (e.g., (\u003ca href=\"#b96\">96\u003c/a>)), and similarities of ocd and tic-related behaviors to some autism-related rrbs, these findings suggest the possibility that rrbs among individuals with the later-onset subtype of asd may, like some other asd-related traits, differ in their manifestations and causes from individuals with early-onset asd.\u003c/p>\u003cp class=\"mb15\">a second limitation identified here is a substantial underrepresentation of girls in studies examining dhea and dheas levels and their effects on asd traits, leaving critical gaps in understanding potential sex-specific patterns. considering the developmental trajectories of asd traits and the dynamic changes in dhea and dheas during middle childhood, future research should prioritize longitudinal designs to better capture how hormonal fluctuations may influence social and cognitive adaptations over time. these studies should include diverse populations to address gaps in gender and ethnic representation and ensure findings are broadly applicable. indeed, only one of the populations represented in this review, from china (\u003ca href=\"#b72\">72\u003c/a>), was not ethnically caucasian or middle eastern. investigations should also aim to elucidate the neurobiological mechanisms underlying these relationships, particularly the roles of dhea and dheas in modulating neural circuits involved in social cognition, including the amygdala, insula, and prefrontal cortex, to provide deeper insights into how hormonal dysregulation during critical developmental windows contributes to the heterogeneity of asd phenotypes.\u003c/p>\u003ca id=\"h6\" name=\"h6\">\u003c/a>\u003ch2>data availability statement\u003c/h2>\u003cp class=\"mb0\">the original contributions presented in the study
